SPX +0.07% at 2710, NASDAQ 100 -0.06% at 6909, DJI -0.22% at 25053

US Treasury futures sold off on Monday as investors await on Wednesday’s crucial CPI data for January, where a strong print could tilt a data-dependent Fed to a more hawkish stance. The sell off was exacerbated going into the US equity open, with positive China-US trade comments from White House Advisor Kelly Conway and a block sale of 8k+ TUH9 by a real money account. Treasuries continued selling off through the session where nine investment grade issuances flooded the market. Looking at the curve on the close, most of the actions was concentrated in the belly of the curve where yields were higher by c.3bps. Spreads were mixed where there was steepening in the front-end with 2s/5s widening by 0.8bps, whilst spreads at the belly to long-end flattened. US T-note futures (H9) settled 8 ticks lower at 122-04.

content:

US MARKET WRAP 11 Feb 2019: Commodities weighed by DXY hitting new YTD high

* SNAP SHOT: Equities mixed, dollar up, Treasuries down, crude down.

* REAR VIEW: Trump and Xi mulling a summit, Fed’s Bowman content with current policy, EU’s Barnier warms to Corbyn’s Brexit, US gives PDVSA license for (some) transactions.

* AHEAD: Australian NAB Business Conditions & Confidence, Japanese Corporate Goods Price, ECB’s Nowotny & Lautenschlaeger Speaking, Fed’s Powell & Mester Speaking, BoE’s Carney Speaking, US President Trump El Paso Rally, UK PM May Updating House of Commons on Brexit, OPEC Monthly Oil Report.

 

* TRADE: White House Adviser Kelly Conway said on Monday that it looks like the US and China are getting closer to a trade deal and it is possible that Trump and Xi will meet very soon. Also reports in Politico suggested that President Trump's strong desire to get a market-boosting deal suggests he is not likely to allow talks to collapse in ways that would more than double tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese exports to the U.S. on March 2, although Trump may be willing to allow it if China does not offer much to the US in Beijing this week. In regard to the March 1st deadline, a senior official said that if Trump and Xi agreed on an extension over the phone, the two leaders would likely stage a summit later in the month; Chinese officials later proposed that they meet on the island of Hainan - close to the Boao Forum for Asia - between March 26th-29th.

* BREXIT: EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier reiterated that following meetings with the Irish and the British, the Brexit deal will not be reopened and it is his understanding UK PM May is not seeking an extension of article 50. However, Barnier said he was interested in UK opposition leader Corbyn’s Brexit letter, which adhered for a customs union and the UK being aligned with the Single Market; Barnier also said the EU has moved towards British positions in the existing deal, particularly the Irish backstop. Looking ahead, UK PM May is to update the House of Commons tomorrow on the progress she has made on Brexit.

* WTI (H9) FUTURES SETTLED USD 0.31 LOWER AT USD 52.41/BBL, BRENT (J9) FUTURES SETTLED USD 0.59 LOWER AT USD 61.51/BBL. In the US pre-market, there was a constructive risk tone which saw equity futures in positive territory. However, the crude complex did not want to participate, breaking last week's dynamic where oil took its cue from stock indices. Desks were struggling to provide a convincing narrative as to why crude was lagging; some had suggested that comments from the UAE (expect markets to reach a balance in Q1, noted excellent compliance, and suggested there was little more that OPEC and its partners needed to do to balance the market). Elsewhere, desks attributed USD strength (fresh YTD highs for the DXY) for the softness in crude. Near the European close, it was reported that Venezuela's PDVSA has been issued licenses by the US Treasury authorising some transactions, which may have been known to market participants earlier; Venezuela continues to try and sell more crude to India, despite questions of whether it will be able to deliver. "Production has been trending lower over the past two years and there are fresh forecasts in circulation that have output falling from its recent 1.2 mmbpd rate to 0.7 mmbpd or less for 2020," Citi said. On the note of compliance, attention will be on this week's monthly reports from EIA, OPEC and IEA; while compliance is generally good across the board, some have noted that Iraq is an outlier. "Platts reported that Iraq’s January crude production grew by 110kb/d to 4.575mb/d, above Iraq’s quota of 4.513mb/d under the OPEC+ agreement," UBS notes, "monthly reports released tomorrow and Wednesday by the EIA, OPEC and the IEA should reassure that enough is being done to avoid an excessively loose market," and argues that "the near-term risk is that supply/demand balances over-tighten as planned and unplanned cuts double up, which should offset all but the most extreme demand decline scenarios and keep the oil price moving higher." This week’s inventories see crude building by 2.3mln, distillates drawing by 1.1mln, gasoline building 0.5mln and cushing building 0.031mln.

* FED: Fed's Bowan (Voter) stated that both the US economy and the Fed's policy are in a good place, adding that she is comfortable with the current stance of policy. She continues to see great job numbers and solid wage growth.

* SPX +0.07% at 2710, NASDAQ -0.06% at 6909, DJI -0.22% at 25053. SECTORS: Energy +0.45%, Materials +0.16%, Industrials +0.54%, Cons Discretionary +0.17%, Cons Staples +0.20%, Healthcare -0.14%, Financials +0.25%, Tech 0.00%, Telecoms -0.63%, Utilities -0.09%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Electronic Arts (EA) outperformed at the open as investors turn optimistic on its new Apex Legends game as well as an upgrade at BAML, but pared back gains into the close; competitor Activision Blizzard (ATVI) underperformed amidst job cuts and ahead of its earnings tomorrow, Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) also traded lower. Loews (L) underperformed after reporting a loss and disappointing revenue. Norfolk Southern (NSC) surged on announcement of a new strategic plan to increase its profitability. Tesla (TSLA) opened higher after an upgrade at Canaccord. Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) traded lower following downgrades at Argus and Longbow. Salesforce.com (CRM) benefitted from a stake increase from Daniel Loeb’s Third Point. NuVasive (NUVA) opened higher after the UK-based Smith & Nephew announced plans to acquire it.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H9) SETTLED 8 TICKS LOWER AT 122-04. US Treasury futures sold off on Monday as investors await on Wednesday’s crucial CPI data for January, where a strong print could tilt a data-dependent Fed to a more hawkish stance. The sell off was exacerbated going into the US equity open, with positive China-US trade comments from White House Advisor Kelly Conway and a block sale of 8k+ TUH9 by a real money account. Treasuries continued selling off through the session where nine investment grade issuances flooded the market. Looking at the curve on the close, most of the actions was concentrated in the belly of the curve where yields were higher by c.3bps. Spreads were mixed where there was steepening in the front-end with 2s/5s widening by 0.8bps, whilst spreads at the belly to long-end flattened.

* DXY: The Dollar is now firmer vs all G10 counterparts, and the index moved ahead of 97.000 to set a new 2019 peak at 97.123, breaching the bullish chart objective at 97.116.

* JPY: The major laggard all day, and extending losses across the board ahead of the return of Japanese markets from National Foundation Day. Usd/Jpy saw buy-stops once 110.16 was cleared (last Monday’s high) and rallied to a fresh ytd pinnacle of 110.45, just shy of 31 December 2018’s peak, while Jpy crosses continues to climb.

* GBP, CHF: The Pound and Franc are vying for the dubious honour of next biggest G10 loser as Cable let go of the 1.2900 handle and fell below the 100 DMA (circa 1.2892) to retest lows not seen since last Thursday’s BoE minutes and QIR (1.2868 vs 1.2857 respectively). The catalysts beyond bearish techs, ongoing Brexit uncertainty and weaker than forecast UK data. Conversely, Swiss CPI matched consensus, but the Chf weakened vs the Usd, albeit not to the extent that it did overnight when Japan holiday impacted trading volumes exacerbated a sharp slide – Usd/Chf now around 1.0040 vs almost 1.0100 at one stage and 0.9900 at the low.

* NOK, EUR, AUD: The next weakest links, with the Nok undermined softer than expected Norwegian inflation data, albeit off worst levels vs the Eur as the single currency also depreciated, cross currently around 9.8100 from almost 9.8400. Meanwhile, Eur/Usd lost grip of 1.1300 and the 30 DMA at 1.1296 on its way to a marginal new base for the year at 1.1282 vs 1.1289 previously before gleaning some traction. The Aud reversed early overnight gains made in part with the aid of firm iron ore prices, and got to within a few pips of last week’s post-RBA Lowe and SOMP lows vs the Usd at 0.7065, while the Aud/Nzd cross slipped back below 1.0500, as the Kiwi remained above its 100 DMA vs the Usd (0.6725), albeit just within a 0.6773-32 range.

* EM: Broad losses vs the buoyant Buck, but with the Rouble deriving some underlying support from Moody’s Russian ratings upgrade, in stark contrast to the Rand that is also under pressure due to Eskom issues. Usd/Rub sub-65.7000 and Usd/Zar around 13.7500 vs highs and lows of 65.7810 and 13.5880 respectively.

Earnings

DJIA

Elsewhere, supply chains sources say MacBook shipments are expected to fall compared to 2018, whilst AirPods and Apple Watch shipments are expected to increase. S&P500

NASDAQ

  • Tesla (TSLA) – The electric automaker has laid off more than half of its 230-member, Model 3 delivery team, hinting at a lowering of the co.’s expected pace of deliveries in the near-term. Elsewhere, CEO Elon Musk has gone to Norway to address service issues in the midst of angered customers who face delays for their Model 3 vehicles. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Bluebird bio (BLUE) – The medtech co. has appointed Amicus Therapeutics’ (FOLD) CFO as its new CFO; effective Feb 11. (Newswires)
  • NuVasive (NUVA) – The British medtech co. Smith & Nephew is mulling the acquisition of NuVasive for USD 3bln. (Newswires)

  • TransCanada (TRP) – The energy co. has said its Keystone pipeline is the likely cause of an oil leak near St. Louis, Missouri, and has no projected restart time for the affected area of the line. (Newswires)
  • Vale (VALE) – The Brazilian miner has denied owning the type of mine-waste that caused the 157-casualty dam collapse in January. (WSJ)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 11th February 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Risk appetite has supported EU stocks (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.8%) ahead of crucial trade talks this week
  • DXY gains more ground, eyeing YTD highs and then the 97.000 mark
  • Bipartisan talks over the weekend regarding funding for the border wall is said to have reached a stalemate ahead of this week’s government shutdown deadline
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian Trade Balance, Fed’s Bowman

ASIA

Asia equity markets began the week mixed following the similar performance of their US peers on Friday and with participants also cautious ahead of this week’s US-China trade discussions, while a stalemate regarding border wall funding also spurred fresh US government shutdown fears. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was negative with the index dragged by losses in the top-weighted financials sector and with focus on several corporate updates, while the absence of Japanese markets for National Founding Day has contributed to the uninspiring tone. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.3%) were initially choppy on China’s return from the week-long closure amid trade-related uncertainty and expectations of a drain in liquidity which is typically the case following the Lunar New Year holidays, although mainland stocks later found support in tandem with outperformance in Shenzhen.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 20bln, while there were separate reports that over CNY 1.0tln of PBoC lending operations will expire this week. (Newswires/China Securities Journal)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7495 (Prev. 6.7081)

China GDP is expected to slow to 6.3% for this year, while it was also suggested that Q1 GDP may slow to 6.0% which would be the weakest start to the year on record. (China Daily/FT)

US President Trump's advisers are said to have informally discussed holding a summit at Mar-a-Lago next month with Chinese President Xi as part of an attempt to end the trade dispute. (Axios)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and USTR Lighthizer to go to China for trade meetings on February 14-15 and deputy-level talks are to begin on February 11. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump tweeted a comment that suggested he is on sound legal ground to declare a National Emergency, while he also noted that Border Committee Democrats are all of a sudden behaving irrationally. Furthermore, it was separately reported that bipartisan talks over the weekend regarding funding for the border wall is said to have reached a stalemate ahead of this week’s government shutdown deadline. (Twitter)

UK/EU

UK PM May has agreed to talks with Labour leader Corbyn regarding a soft Brexit according to The Telegraph, although it was separately reported that UK PM May rejected a pivot towards a Brexit customs union compromise. Nonetheless, should May engage in discussions with Corbyn on entering into a customs union, The Times reports that this could see the PM lose support from some members of her cabinet. (Telegraph/Newswires)

UK PM May spokesman says PM May will made a statement to Parliament tomorrow, not on Wednesday. Spokesman says No10 are "absolutely clear" that they are not considering Corbyn's customs proposal. (Newswires)

A leading thinktank,The Institute for Fiscal Studies, has revealed that UK Chancellor Hammond will need to find an extra GBP 5bln this year to meet his claims of ending austerity. (The Guardian)

UK Chancellor Hammond says now is not the time for an Article 50 extension. (Newswires)

Swiss Govt. confirms they have signed a trade agreement with the UK; will come into effect when the Swiss/EU agreements don't apply to relations between the UK and Switzerland) Elsewhere, Italy is forming emergency plans to safeguard financial stability and keep trade with the UK flowing even if there is a no-deal Brexit. (Telegraph)

UK GDP Prelimiary YY Q4 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.5%, Rev. 1.6%)

- GDP Preliminary QQ Q4 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.6%)

- UK Industrial Output YY Dec -0.9% vs. Exp. -0.4% (Prev. -1.5%, Rev. -1.3%)

Italy’s coalition government is reportedly in sharp disagreement over protecting the Bank of Italy’s independence after central bankers issued more pessimistic economic growth forecasts this year. (FT)

Italian Deputy PM Salvini says that the idea of using gold reserves to plug budget holes could be interesting. (Newswires)

ECB’s de Guindos says he expects inflation in the Eurozone to continue to slow in the coming months, and higher underlying inflation in the medium term. Adding that interest rates are expected to remain at present levels ‘at least through the summer of 2019’.

GEOPOLITICAL

US General said withdrawal of US forces from Syria is likely to begin in weeks dependent on conditions on the ground, while he added that US troop levels in Iraq are to remain steady. (Newswires)

UK Defence Minister said Britain should enhance military lethality post-Brexit and must show it will act when needed, while he added that Russia provocation must come at a cost. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

All Major European Indices are in the green [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.8%], strengthening from the mixed trade seen in Asia overnight. FTSE MIB (+1.5%) is the outperforming index largely due to strength in banking names, with Banco BPM (+7.2%), BPER Banca (+5.6%), UBI Banca (+3.5%) and Intesa Sanpaolo (+1.9%) in the green following ECB SREP capital requirement updates. Following this, all sectors are higher with some outperformance seen in the financial sector. Other notable movers include Smith & Nephew (-4.8%) who are towards the bottom of the Stoxx 600, after reports that the Co. are to acquire NuVasive in a deal worth over USD 3bln. Elsewhere, Euronext (+0.6%) have been choppy after they increased their offer for Oslo Bors; who have stated they still prefer a takeover by Nasdaq. Just Eat (+2.1%) are in the green as shareholder Cat Rock Capital have stated the Co. should engage in merger discussions. In terms of US premarket news, Apple’s iPhone shipments to China decreased by an estimated 20% in Q4 as Huawei’s grip on the market strengthened; the Co. are up by around 0.3% in the pre-market.

FX

USD - The Dollar remains underpinned heading in to the next round of US-China trade talks, and with further impetus derived from ongoing weakness in rival currencies. The DXY has inched higher as a result and is now testing nearest resistance around 96.809 ahead of 97.000 and the next upside chart target at 97.116.

JPY - The G10 underperformer and major mover, partly due to thinner trading conditions overnight as Japanese markets were shut for National Foundation Day. However, the Jpy was also hit by cross demand and the headline pair has subsequently cleared last Monday’s 110.16 high that had been containing gains to trade up at 110.27.

CHF/GBP/NOK- Also considerably weaker, but the Franc has recovered relatively well from an abrupt slide to almost 1.1000 vs the Usd and back through 1.1400 vs the Eur as a combination of stops and model-driven buy orders were triggered in the aforementioned illiquid holiday impacted Asian session, with some talk that the move could have been prompted by an erroneous trade. Note, the Chf largely shrugged off in line Swiss CPI in stark contrast to Sterling and the Norwegian Krona that both extended losses in wake of data (GDP, IP, manufacturing and construction output in the case of the former, and inflation for the latter). Indeed, Cable fell from circa 1.2955 to around 1.2895 and only a few pips from the 100 DMA (1.2892), while Eur/Nok climbed to just shy of 9.8400 vs sub-9.7700 at one stage.

EUR - Notwithstanding the cross Jpy demand noted above, the single currency has dipped under 1.1300 vs the Greenback to test bids/support around key downside chart levels at 1.1296 (30 DMA) and 1.1289 (current 2019 low). No fresh bearish catalyst or new driver, but the Eur is still being undermined by slowing Eurozone growth, inflation and political jitters.

NZD/AUD/SEK - All bucking the overall trend and/or holding up better vs broadly firm Usd, with the Kiwi gleaning some encouragement after keeping its head above the 100 DMA (0.6725) to probe above 0.6750 and the 200 DMA (0.6756), but unable to clear 0.6775. Meanwhile, the Aud continues to consolidate after last week’s heavy RBA-related losses, and hover just under 0.7100/1.0500 vs its US and NZ counterparts, and the Swedish Krona has rebounded above 10.5000 vs the Eur amidst relative gains vs its Scandinavian peer.

RUB - The Rouble has been choppy between 65.3975 and 65.7655, with initial strength seen following Moody’s ratings upgrade whittled away by the generally bid Usd and another dip in Brent crude prices.

FIXED INCOME

The core 10 year EU bonds have pared losses, with Gilts reclaiming 124.00 with a little more conviction in wake of the raft of mostly weaker than forecast UK data, while Bunds may have taken some solace from holding above last Friday’s Eurex base to trade back over 166.40, albeit just as EU equities remain firm and Italian BTPs even firmer than they were earlier (126.50 new high). Elsewhere, US Treasuries have slipped from overnight session peaks and the curve is fractionally steeper ahead of a speech by Fed’s Bowman, and potentially more data in the form of Q4 labour costs and productivity.

COMMODITIES 

Brent (-0.3%) and WTI (-0.9%) prices have weakened on the cautious risk tone ahead of this week’s US-China trade talks. In terms of recent news flow UAE Energy Minister Al Mazroui has stated that the OPEC+ compliance was excellent in January, he sees a balanced oil market in Q1 2019 and no further action is required by OPEC+. In spite of Friday’s Baker Hughes Rig Count which saw oil rigs increase by 7, adding to the concern that record US production will hamper the OPEC+ production cuts. Separately, the Venezuelan Oil Minister stated that their oil output is currently at 1.57mln BPD, and the country are looking to expand their cooperation with India. Looking ahead OPEC are due to release their monthly oil report tomorrow, which includes January production estimates; separately, the IEA are to release their report on Wednesday.

Gold (-0.5%) prices are weighed on by dollar strength, in spite of the uncertain risk tone seen overnight ahead of US-China trade talks. Elsewhere, iron ore futures have jumped up by over 8% today as China returns to the market following the holiday period for Chinese New Year. Separately, UBS say the iron ore market faces a deficit of 30mln tonnes due to the Vale dam collapse.

UBS said iron ore market faces deficit of 30mln tons due to Vale crisis. (Newswires)

Venezuelan Oil Minister says the country is looking to expand cooperation with India; adding that the country’s oil output currently stands at 1.57mln BPD. Also stating that US oil sanctions on the country are impacting production (Newswires)

UAE Energy Minister Al Mazroui says OPEC+ cuts compliance was excellent in January; adding that he sees a balanced oil market in Q1 2019 and no further action is need by OPEC+. Adding that oil output stands at 3.07mln BPD, and that he remains optamisitc about the actions taken by OPEC and Non-OPEC. (Newswires)

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo says sanctions on Venezuela and Iran are to effect the oil market all year. (Newswires)

BOFA expect OPEC production to decline in 2019-24 due to output curbs, sanctions (on Iran and Venezuela) and insufficient investments. (Newswures)

Separately, UBS say the iron ore market faces a deficit of 30mln tonnes due to the Vale dam collapse.

subject: Fixed Income: some lines drawn in the sand
content: The core 10 year EU bonds have pared losses, with Gilts reclaiming 124.00 with a little more conviction in wake of the raft of mostly weaker than forecast UK data, while Bunds may have taken some solace from holding above last Friday’s Eurex base to trade back over 166.40, albeit just as EU equities remain firm and Italian BTPs even firmer than they were earlier (126.50 new high). Elsewhere, US Treasuries have slipped from overnight session peaks and the curve is fractionally steeper ahead of a speech by Fed’s Bowman, and potentially more data in the form of Q4 labour costs and productivity.

subject: FX Morning Colour: cross winds, flash crash and detrimental data
content:
USD

The Dollar remains underpinned heading in to the next round of US-China trade talks, and with further impetus derived from ongoing weakness in rival currencies. The DXY has inched higher as a result and is now testing nearest resistance around 96.809 ahead of 97.000 and the next upside chart target at 97.116.

JPY

The G10 underperformer and major mover, partly due to thinner trading conditions overnight as Japanese markets were shut for National Foundation Day. However, the Jpy was also hit by cross demand and the headline pair has subsequently cleared last Monday’s 110.16 high that had been containing gains to trade up at 110.27.

CHF/GBP/NOK

Also considerably weaker, but the Franc has recovered relatively well from an abrupt slide to almost 1.1000 vs the Usd and back through 1.1400 vs the Eur as a combination of stops and model-driven buy orders were triggered in the aforementioned illiquid holiday impacted Asian session, with some talk that the move could have been prompted by an erroneous trade. Note, the Chf largely shrugged off in line Swiss CPI in stark contrast to Sterling and the Norwegian Krona that both extended losses in wake of data (GDP, IP, manufacturing and construction output in the case of the former, and inflation for the latter). Indeed, Cable fell from circa 1.2955 to around 1.2895 and only a few pips from the 100 DMA (1.2892), while Eur/Nok climbed to just shy of 9.8400 vs sub-9.7700 at one stage.

EUR

Notwithstanding the cross Jpy demand noted above, the single currency has dipped under 1.1300 vs the Greenback to test bids/support around key downside chart levels at 1.1296 (30 DMA) and 1.1289 (current 2019 low). No fresh bearish catalyst or new driver, but the Eur is still being undermined by slowing Eurozone growth, inflation and political jitters.

NZD/AUD/SEK

All bucking the overall trend and/or holding up better vs broadly firm Usd, with the Kiwi gleaning some encouragement after keeping its head above the 100 DMA (0.6725) to probe above 0.6750 and the 200 DMA (0.6756), but unable to clear 0.6775. Meanwhile, the Aud continues to consolidate after last week’s heavy RBA-related losses, and hover just under 0.7100/1.0500 vs its US and NZ counterparts, and the Swedish Krona has rebounded above 10.5000 vs the Eur amidst relative gains vs its Scandinavian peer.

RUB  

The Rouble has been choppy between 65.3975 and 65.7655, with initial strength seen following Moody’s ratings upgrade whittled away by the generally bid Usd and another dip in Brent crude prices.

content: Bunds and Gilts have both extended losses as EU equities climb further and some near term technical/psychological support levels give way. The former has now been down to 166.30 (-45 ticks on the day) with stops likely exacerbating the downturn once 166.48 was breached and 166.38 failed to arrest further downside, while the latter probably tripped sell orders on the break of Friday’s 124.02 Liffe session base and then 124.00 on the way down to 123.89. Next chart supports are seen at 166.26 (Friday’s Eurex low) and 123.70/69 respectively, but UK data imminent.

ECB's de Guindos says expects inflation in the Eurozone to continue to slow in the coming months
content:
• Expects to see higher underlying inflation over the medium term
  • Interest rates are expected to remain at their present levels “at least through the summer of 2019”.
  • But, in addition, there is a state-contingent element, rates will remain unchanged “in any case for as long as necessary to ensure the continued sustained convergence of inflation to levels that are below, but close to, 2% over the medium term

subject: UK debt and STIR futures fade after firm start to Liffe
content: Gilts and Short Sterling contracts kicked off Monday’s session on the front foot, but have turned tail relatively quickly to trade more in line with the softer tone in core counterparts, as the FTSE joins its peers in positive territory. The 10 year benchmark opened 9 ticks above its 124.35 previous settlement level, but has subsequently slipped to a 124.14 low, while the 3 month strip has reversed early gains of 0.5-1 tick. Ahead, a front-loaded start to the week in terms of domestic data with GDP in focus via the first look at Q4 growth and the rolling ONS series for December, but ip, manufacturing production and trade also scheduled.

subject: ECB says banks borrowed EUR 50mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 658.6 with it overnight

Bunds: some consolidation after rally and 0.1% yield breach
content: The 10 year German debt future has lost momentum after last week’s run up to fresh contract highs and retreat in the corresponding yield to single digit territory amidst tentative signs of an improvement in broad risk sentiment via firmer EU equity futures ahead of the cash bourse opens, and a firm bounce in Italian BTPs. However, it remains to be seen whether the pull-back in Bunds and uptick in yields is transitory or a more meaningful retracement. Bunds currently near the bottom of a 166.49-73 range vs Friday’s 166.75 Eurex close and the 166.83 intraday peak, while 10 year cash is hovering just below 0.10%. Ahead, no Eurozone data, but a speech from ECB’s de Guindos may provide some interest.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

11th February 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mixed following the similar performance of their US peers on Friday and with participants also cautious ahead of this week’s US-China trade discussions, while a stalemate regarding border wall funding also spurred fresh US government shutdown fears. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was negative with the index dragged by losses in the top-weighted financials sector and with focus on several corporate updates, while the absence of Japanese markets for National Founding Day has contributed to the uninspiring tone. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) were initially choppy on China’s return from the week-long closure amid trade-related uncertainty and expectations of a drain in liquidity which is typically the case following the Lunar New Year holidays, although mainland stocks later found support in tandem with outperformance in Shenzhen.

FTSE

Imperial Brands (IMB LN) – Co. are expected to announce that Chairman Mark Williamson will step down in the upcoming months; following the introduction of more stringent rules regarding corporate governance. (The Times)

Just Eat (JE/ LN) – Cat Rock Capital say the Co. should engage in merger talks with industry peers; adding that they are concerned with the Co. recent executive appointments and that a merger would be a good outcome for Co. shareholders. (Newswires)

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – Iceland is reportedly considering a move to acquire any of the Co’s and ASDA stores that they are required to sell for regulatory purposes. The Competition and Markets Authority is expected to release provisional findings of its probe into the Sainsbury’s-ASDA merger as early as this week. (FT)

Smith & Nephew (SN/ LN) – Co. has reportedly held talks to acquire spinal surgery equipment maker NuVasive in a deal that would be worth over USD 3bln. (FT)

Barclays (BARC LN) – Co.’s incoming chairman is reportedly under immediate pressure from shareholders to shake-up Co.’s board. (Telegraph) This follows FT’s report last week that Activist investor Bramson is said to be looking at shaking up Barclay's board at the company's annual meeting in May; according to a statement from Sherborne Investor.

Lloyds (LLOY LN) – Co. is said to plan to hire over 700 financial advisers in a bid to increase its assets under management from about GBP 13bln to GBP 25bln within the next five years; according to an internal document seen by FT. (FT)

Ocado (OCDO LN) – Co. have denied reports that in The Times that robots within the factory interfered with efforts by firefighter to extinguish a fire at the Co’s Andover warehouse. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Metro Bank (MTRO LN) – Co.’s shareholders have asked Stewarts Law, the UK’s largest litigation-only law firm, to consider representing them in a loan-related legal dispute. (Telegraph)

BROKER MOVES

LLOYDS (LLOY LN) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUALWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

RBS (RBS LN) DOWNGRADED TO EQUALWEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

PETROFAC (PFC LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

METRO BANK (MTRO LN) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL AT BERENBERG

TALKTALK (TALK LN) DOWNGRADED TO REDUCE FROM HOLD AT HSBC

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Adam Schiff, the US Democratic Chairman of the House Intelligence Committee has raised concerns that Special Council Mueller may not be investigating US President Trump’s links to the Co. Separately, Co. has had to pay the highest financing rates on the euro debt market for a leading international bank this year. Co. last week sold a total of EUR 3.6bln in euro-denominated debt, paying 180bps above benchmark for a 2yr bond. (Newswires/FT)

Siemens (SIE GY) – Co’s and General Electrics (GE) business hopes in Iraq have been set back as Iraq’ energy minster says that a lack of resources and bureaucracy are hampering his ability to complete large deals with multinationals. (FT)

Bayer (BAYN GY) – Brazilian soy farmers have accused the Co. of violating a court order on the Intacta patent dispute. (Newswires)

Deutsche Lufthansa (LHA GY) – UFO cabin crew talks have reportedly broken down amid a lack of agreement on profit sharing. (Newswires)

Deutsche Post (DPW GY) - Co.’s planned mail price increase is to be delayed during the summer this year; according to German press. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Carl Zeiss (AFX GY) – Q1 EBIT EUR 48.1mln vs. Prev. EUR 38.9mln. Q1 revenue EUR 323.6mln vs. Prev. EUR 294.7mln. Co. expects to grow at least as fast as the market for fiscal 2018/19. Co. confirms their margin target. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SUEDZUCKER (SZU GY) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL BANKHAUS LAMPE

CAC

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Euronext (ENX FP) – Co. have raised their offer for Oslo Bors from NOK 145 to NOK 158 per share; the acceptance period has been increased by 4 weeks to March 11th. Co. add that the acquisition is already supported by a majority of Oslo Bors share holders. (Newswires)

Thales (HO FP) – Co. have appointed Peggy Nahmanny as VP. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Intesa Sanpaolo (ISP IM) – Co. say they meet the ECB’s capital requirements; CET1 ratio of 13.5% at the end of 2018, fully loaded requirement is 9.33%. (Newswires)

BPER (BPE IM) – Unipol CEO notes that they are to lift their stake in the Co. (Newswires)

Banco BPM (BAMI IM) – The ECB has requested a total SREP capital requirement of 10.25% for this year, while it cut the Pillar 2 requirement for the bank by 25bps to 2.25%. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

UNICREDIT (UCG IM) REITERATED OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

SMI

UBS (UBSG SW) – Co. has overhauled its pay policy for 10k staff in an attempt to reduce uncertainty about bonuses. Employees at the bank’s “corporate centre” will no longer receive variable bonuses, the bank confirmed. Separately, the ECB has requested a total SREP capital requirement of 13.57% at group level for this year. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

Galp Energia (GALP SW) – Q4 adj. EBITDA EUR 493mln vs. Prev. EUR 476mln, net adj. profit EUR 109mln vs. Prev. EUR 189mln. Co. sees 2019 EBITDA at EUR 2.1 - 2.2 bln, and above EUR 3bln from 2020 onwards. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

Danske Bank (DANSKE DC) – A group of up to 70 investors, who have collective damage claims of EUR 1bln are reportedly close to filing a complaint against the Co.; concerning losses related to money laundering allegations involving the Co. (Telegraph)

BROKER MOVES

US

SPX +0.1% at 2708, NASDAQ +0.1% at 7299, DJI +0.3% at 25104. SECTORS: Energy -0.9%, Materials -0.2%, Industrials +0.0%, Cons Discretionary -0.7%, Cons Staples +0.4%, Healthcare +0.0%, Financials -0.7%, Tech +0.4%, Telecoms +0.3%, Utilities +0.4%.

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 11th February 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets began the week mixed following the similar performance of their US peers on Friday and ahead of US-China trade talks
  • UK PM May has agreed to talks with Labour leader Corbyn regarding a soft Brexit according to The Telegraph; later reports suggest she has rejected this potential pivot
  • CHF saw volatility overnight amid a mini ‘flash-crash’ which saw the currency weaken by 1% which some attributed to stops being taken out amid thin liquidity
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Swiss CPI, UK GDP, Production & Trade, ECB’s de Guindos

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week mixed following the similar performance of their US peers on Friday and with participants also cautious ahead of this week’s US-China trade discussions, while a stalemate regarding border wall funding also spurred fresh US government shutdown fears. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was negative with the index dragged by losses in the top-weighted financials sector and with focus on several corporate updates, while the absence of Japanese markets for National Founding Day has contributed to the uninspiring tone. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) were initially choppy on China’s return from the week-long closure amid trade-related uncertainty and expectations of a drain in liquidity which is typically the case following the Lunar New Year holidays, although mainland stocks later found support in tandem with outperformance in Shenzhen.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 20bln, while there were separate reports that over CNY 1.0tln of PBoC lending operations will expire this week. (Newswires/China Securities Journal)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7495 (Prev. 6.7081)

China GDP is expected to slow to 6.3% for this year, while it was also suggested that Q1 GDP may slow to 6.0% which would be the weakest start to the year on record. (China Daily/FT)

US President Trump's advisers are said to have informally discussed holding a summit at Mar-a-Lago next month with Chinese President Xi as part of an attempt to end the trade dispute. Separately, there were reports on Friday that the China trade deadline of March 1st could move according to a senior administration official. (Axios/CNBC)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and USTR Lighthizer to go to China for trade meetings on February 14-15 and deputy-level talks are to begin on February 11. In related news, there were reports that many of the concessions Beijing is offering appear to be rehashes of measures previously announced. (Newswires/Nikkei)


UK/EU

UK PM May has agreed to talks with Labour leader Corbyn regarding a soft Brexit according to The Telegraph, although it was separately reported that UK PM May rejected a pivot towards a Brexit customs union compromise. Nonetheless, should May engage in discussions with Corbyn on entering into a customs union, The Times reports that this could see the PM lose support from some members of her cabinet. (Telegraph/Newswires)

Irish PM Varadkar said on balance he believes a deal can be secured but is unsure if it can be done by the end of March or after an extension. (Newswires)

A leading thinktank, The Institute for Fiscal Studies, has revealed that UK Chancellor Hammond will need to find an extra GBP 5bln this year to meet his claims of ending austerity. (The Guardian)

UK and Switzerland have struck an agreement that will allow the two nations to trade without any additional tariffs after the UK leaves the EU. (Newswires) Elsewhere, Italy is forming emergency plans to safeguard financial stability and keep trade with the UK flowing even if there is a no-deal Brexit. (Telegraph)

Italy’s coalition government is reportedly in sharp disagreement over protecting the Bank of Italy’s independence after central bankers issued more pessimistic economic growth forecasts this year. (FT)

Fitch affirmed Greece at BB-, Outlook Stable. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, the DXY remained firm and in proximity to its YTD highs as its counterparts traded mixed with EUR/USD and GBP/USD at the bottom halves of the 1.1300 and 1.2900 handles respectively, while antipodeans outperformed but have much further to go to recover from the aftermath of the RBA’s recent dovish shift to its rate outlook and poor New Zealand jobs data. Elsewhere, price action in USD/JPY was initially contained by the lack of Japanese participants before a slight improvement in risk tone provided some mild support, while CHF began the day volatile in which an early mini flash-crash saw the currency weaken by 1% which some attributed to stops being taken out amid thin liquidity, although the move was later pared given the lack of news catalysts.



COMMODITIES

Commodities mostly weakened amid the cautious risk tone overnight which pressured WTI crude futures towards the USD 52.00/bbl level where it has found some support. Elsewhere, gold prices saw mild losses as the greenback held near last week’s best levels and copper failed to benefit from China’s return to the market as trade uncertainty and US shutdown concerns dampened broader market sentiment, while Dalian iron ore futures bucked the trend as they played catch up to global prices and hit limit up shortly after the open on Vale-related supply concerns.

Baker Hughes Rig Count (8/Feb): Total rigs +4 at 1059; oil rigs +7 at 854; gas rigs -3 at 195. (Newswires)


UBS said iron ore market faces deficit of 30mln tons due to Vale crisis. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICS

US General said withdrawal of US forces from Syria is likely to begin in weeks dependent on conditions on the ground, while he added that US troop levels in Iraq are to remain steady. (Newswires)

UK Defence Minister said Britain should enhance military lethality post-Brexit and must show it will act when needed, while he added that Russia provocation must come at a cost. (Newswires)
 

US

Much of the movement in the T-Note was sideways on Friday, with a slight upward bias, inspired by the usual cocktail of lingering concerns over US/China trade, and global growth. A brief dip in the pre-market was attributed to dealers unloading auction long positions, while Bunds were providing some influence in early trade too. Profit-taking at the end of the European day saw some of the gains pared back to leave the T-Note 3 ticks higher at settlement. Major curve spreads were mixed, but generally +/- 1bps at settle. US T-note futures (H9) settled +3 ticks at 122-12.

US President Trump tweeted a comment that suggested he is on sound legal ground to declare a National Emergency, while he also noted that Border Committee Democrats are all of a sudden behaving irrationally. Furthermore, it was separately reported that bipartisan talks over the weekend regarding funding for the border wall is said to have reached a stalemate ahead of this week’s government shutdown deadline. (Twitter)

NEC Director Kudlow and Chief of Staff Mulvaney are said to be mulling departing from the Trump administration. (Vanity Fair)

Fed's Daly (non-voter) said US economy is slowing down and that in itself will help prevent a recession, while also noted financial conditions are tighter now than at the start of 2018. Furthermore, Daly commented that the Fed is discussing whether QE should be used only in emergencies or more readily and that patience is data-dependent not time-dependent. (Newswires)

Commodities mostly weakened amid the cautious risk tone overnight which pressured WTI crude futures towards the USD 52.00/bbl level where it has found some support. Elsewhere, gold prices saw mild losses as the greenback held near last week’s best levels and copper failed to benefit from China’s return to the market as trade uncertainty and US shutdown concerns dampened broader market sentiment, while Dalian iron ore futures bucked the trend as they played catch up to global prices and hit limit up shortly after the open on Vale-related supply concerns.

Baker Hughes Rig Count (8/Feb): Total rigs +4 at 1059; oil rigs +7 at 854; gas rigs -3 at 195. (Newswires)


UBS said iron ore market faces deficit of 30mln tons due to Vale crisis. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICS

US General said withdrawal of US forces from Syria is likely to begin in weeks dependent on conditions on the ground, while he added that US troop levels in Iraq are to remain steady. (Newswires)

UK Defence Minister said Britain should enhance military lethality post-Brexit and must show it will act when needed, while he added that Russia provocation must come at a cost. (Newswires)
 

US

Much of the movement in the T-Note was sideways on Friday, with a slight upward bias, inspired by the usual cocktail of lingering concerns over US/China trade, and global growth. A brief dip in the pre-market was attributed to dealers unloading auction long positions, while Bunds were providing some influence in early trade too. Profit-taking at the end of the European day saw some of the gains pared back to leave the T-Note 3 ticks higher at settlement. Major curve spreads were mixed, but generally +/- 1bps at settle. US T-note futures (H9) settled +3 ticks at 122-12.

US President Trump tweeted a comment that suggested he is on sound legal ground to declare a National Emergency, while he also noted that Border Committee Democrats are all of a sudden behaving irrationally. Furthermore, it was separately reported that bipartisan talks over the weekend regarding funding for the border wall is said to have reached a stalemate ahead of this week’s government shutdown deadline. (Twitter)

NEC Director Kudlow and Chief of Staff Mulvaney are said to be mulling departing from the Trump administration. (Vanity Fair)

Fed's Daly (non-voter) said US economy is slowing down and that in itself will help prevent a recession, while also noted financial conditions are tighter now than at the start of 2018. Furthermore, Daly commented that the Fed is discussing whether QE should be used only in emergencies or more readily and that patience is data-dependent not time-dependent. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades cautious ahead of US-China trade talks and potential US government shutdown
content:
Asia equity markets begin the week with a tentative tone following the mixed performance of their US peers on Friday and with participants also cautious ahead of this week’s US-China trade discussions, while a stalemate regarding border wall funding has also spurred fresh US government shutdown fears. ASX 200 (-0.4%) is negative with the index dragged by losses in the top-weighted financials sector and with focus also on several corporate updates, while the absence of Japanese markets for National Founding Day has also contributed to the uninspiring tone. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) trade choppy on the mainland’s return from the week-long closure amid trade-related uncertainty and expectations of a drain in liquidity which is typically the case following the Lunar New Year holidays.

In FX markets, the DXY is flat and sits in proximity to its YTD highs as its counterparts trade mixed, with EUR/USD and GBP/USD at the bottom halves of the 1.1300 and 1.2900 handles respectively, while antipodeans outperform but have much further to go to recover from last week’s drop in the aftermath of the RBA’s dovish shift to its rate outlook and poor New Zealand jobs data. Elsewhere, price action in USD/JPY is contained by the lack of Japanese participants and CHF began the day volatile as an early flash crash saw the currency weaken by 1% which some attributed to stops being taken out amid thin liquidity, although the move was later pared given the lack of news catalysts.
